column1: The horse was brought round to the door. Now he had not ridden for a great while; and
column2: though the little boys were there to help him
column3: he had great trouble in getting on the horse.He tried a great many times
column4: but always found himself facing the wrong way
column5: looking at the horse's tail. They turned the horse's head
column7: then down the street; it made no difference; he always made some mistake
column8: and found himself sitting the wrong way."Well
column9: said he, at last, I don't know as I care. If the horse has his head in the right direction
column10: that is the main thing. Sometimes I ride this way in the cars
column11: because I like it better. I can turn my head easily enough
column12: to see where we are going." So off he went
column13: and the little boys said he looked like a circus-rider
column14: and they were much pleased.He rode along out of the village
column16: very quietly. Pretty soon he came to a bridge
column17: where the road went across a little stream.
